info.game_comments:
2000 Tournament of Champions final game 2.
From the Atlanta Civic Center.

double_jeopardy_round: THE SIX WIVES OF HENRY VIII

(1, 1).clue: Of WWI, he said, "Our own fortunes as a nation are involved whether we would have it so or not"

(2, 1).clue: On this revival Tom Bergeron explains that you have to get 3 stars in a row, across, up & down or diagonally

(3, 1).clue: Like the thyroid, ovaries are this type of gland that secretes chemicals directly into the bloodstream

(4, 1).clue: His "Legends Of Hollywood" stamp is a dandy; in fact, it shows him from "Yankee Doodle Dandy"

(5, 1).clue: It's the 5-letter word for a large fluffy feather, or a column of smoke

(6, 1).clue: In ads Andy Griffith said, "Everything's great when it sits on" one of these buttery crackers

(1, 2).clue: In 1937 FDR saw this fraction "of a nation ill-housed, ill-clad, ill-nourished"

(2, 2).clue: For the "2000" revival of this Nickelodeon show host Jason Harris is in charge of slime

(3, 2).clue: When your ears "pop", it's actually this tube opening, allowing air to escape from or to the middle ear

(4, 2).clue: The stamps honoring the 1970s include a head shot of this TV star, species "Bigus Canarius"

(5, 2).clue: They're the cute little impressions on a golf ball

(6, 2).clue: It gets its name from the bicarb used to make it

(1, 3).clue: In his 1873 second inaugural, he complained he'd hardly rested since Fort Sumter

(2, 3).clue: The Buybidwin website offers websurfers a chance to play this Monty Hall game for prizes

(3, 3).clue: Human lungs have millions of these tiny air sacs, where oxygen & carbon dioxide are exchanged

(4, 3).clue: Unusual shape of the Pacific 97 stagecoach & ship stamps

(5, 3).clue: A gentle way to cook an egg, it also means to pamper a person, especially a child

(6, 3).clue: Name of the Pepperidge Farm product seen here:

(1, 4).clue: His nearly 2-hour speech in the snow included musings on the history of democracy back to Athens

(2, 4).clue: This grocery store-set game was first seen in 1965, came back in 1990 with host David Ruprecht, & is back on PAX

(3, 4).clue: The 2 main types of these white blood cells are B cells & T cells

(4, 4).clue: A hare is the animal on the seventh stamp in a series commemorating this holiday

(5, 4).clue: Congratulations if you know this word derived from Greek means praise or credit (It's also a granola bar)

(6, 4).clue: The name of this Sunshine Biscuit Co. cracker sounds like a slang phrase used when the cops are coming

(1, 5).clue: In 1857 he called the question of slavery in the territories "Of but little practical importance"

(2, 5).clue: In 1999 Game Show Network revived Chuck Barris' "3's A Crowd" with this former "Growing Pains" star as host

(3, 5).clue: 2 of the 3 sections of the small intestine

(4, 5).clue: A stamp honoring this man includes a photo of Central Park & 2 landscape plans

(5, 5).clue: It can mean the ability to do something, or the body of teachers at a school or college

(6, 5).clue: 2-word term for something crunchy added to chowder, or someone trying to get at a pearl

(1, 1).clue: From 1936 to 1991 the region was the Georgian SSR, SSR standing for this

(3, 1).clue: "Dialogues Des Carmelites" ends in 1790s Paris, so it's no surprise when much of the cast is killed with this device

(4, 1).clue: It's the passage sought but not found by Cartier, Frobisher & Franklin

(5, 1).clue: "You Can't Keep A Good Woman Down" is a book of stories by this Georgia-born author of "The Color Purple"

(6, 1).clue: To supply someone with the necessary tools

(1, 2).clue: Sukhumi & Batumi are Georgian resort cities on this body of water

(3, 2).clue: In a modern opera based on an 1870s novel, this woman loses her train of thought & throws herself in front of a train

(4, 2).clue: This Venetian traveler believed he found the kingdom of legendary King Prester John

(5, 2).clue: "Song Of Solomon" was the first of her novels to have a male protagonist

(1, 3).clue: It's an ob-skewer fact that Georgians enjoy shashlik, also known by this 2-word name

(3, 3).clue: Dr. Miracle tricks Antonia into singing herself to death in "The Tales Of" this author

(4, 3).clue: In 1799 Alexander Von Humboldt set out to prove the Orinoco connects to this longer river

(5, 3).clue: This famed orator who was born a slave wrote the 1855 memoir "My Bondage And My Freedom"

(6, 3).clue: Agreeably pungent, like many a spice

(1, 4).clue: Meliton Balanchivadze, a major Georgian composer, was the father of this choreographer

(3, 4).clue: Brutus Jones shoots himself with a silver bullet in the opera based on this Eugene O'Neill play

(4, 4).clue: Vitus Bering was born in Denmark, but explored the Arctic for this European power

(5, 4).clue: This poet called her 1976 memoir "Singin' And Swingin' And Gettin' Merry Like Christmas"

(6, 4).clue: In this craft you cut out pieces of one material & sew or paste them on to another

(1, 5).clue: Seen here, he was president when Georgia became independent, but was then deposed

(3, 5).clue: Poisoned pastry made by a witch kills a prince & a goose-girl in "Die Konigskinder" by this German composer

(4, 5).clue: 19th century world traveler Isabella Bird was the first female member of this British society founded in 1830

(5, 5).clue: Ernest J. Gaines "Autobiography Of" this fictional woman became an Emmy-winning TV movie starring Cicely Tyson

(6, 5).clue: This herbicide used on marijuana plants was in the news in the '80s

(0, 0).clue: This peninsula of 85,000 square miles was ruled by a single dynasty from 1392 to 1910
